column2: ^2191247^1^0^"I was one of the 'Plane People' who was on their way home to the US on 9/11- when we were diverted to Canada
column3: due to the attacks on our country and the closure of US airspace.

column1: Thirty something jumbo jets landed at Gander
column2: Newfoundland.
a small town
column3: rallied to the cause and 'threw open their doors' to us. They knew our country had been injured and we were hurting as well. They did everything in their power to comfort us and provide assistance.

column2: offering the use of their phones
column3: to cooking meals for us
column4: to opening their homes so we could sleep and shower
column5: to driving us around town- the word 'no' simply did not exist in their vocabulary during that week!

column1: Many of us actually walked away from this experience with guilt. Our country had been attacked by the most evil
column2: vile actors in the world.- and it was hurting We on the other hand
column3: found ourselves surrounded by the most caring
column4: loving folks we had probably ever encountered. It was the greatest contrast possible!

column2: they refused to accept any money
column3: or gifts in appreciation for what they had done for us. They just said 'We can't. You would do the same for us
column4: it was our pleasure'.

column1: A truly uplifting 9/11 story about our neighbors to the north. Thank you again
column2: for all that you did for all of us that came to you as strangers- but departed as friends!"^5^September 13

column2: ^20529315^8^3^"Having recently read Bill O'Reilly's fabulous 'Killing Lincoln' i really had my hopes up for his book on the Kennedy assassination. It's disappointing. Unfortunately the book misses the mark. Most of the book details the years leading up to the assassination

column2: ^3879406^7^0^"Have you ever wondered why some societies in the world are quite developed economically
column3: politically
column4: and militarily
column5: while many more societies in the world have very little wealth
column6: unstable governments
column7: and continually seem on the brink of catastrophe? Guns Germs and Steel is author Jared Diamond's masterpiece in explaining how geographic and environmental conditions are the reasons behind why some countries on this earth 'Have' and why many countries 'Do Not Have.' In only a few hundred pages Diamond changed how I look at and understand the world. If you are someone that wants to know how 'we' as the human race ended up the way we did I strongly recommend this book. If you've ever wondered why things are the way they are
column8: then read this book. In fact
column9: if you've ever wondered about anything
column10: then read this book as an excellent starting point."^5^July 17

column2: ^3879406^3^0^"Diamond's clearly stated thesis is that geography is the great determiner of human destiny
column3: though
column4: weirdly
column5: it is left out of the title of the book. The book actually has little to say about the three items of the title
column6: but rather focuses on the natural resources available to different regions of the world
column7: the animals that could be domesticated
column8: and the possibilities for communicating with other adjacent cultures. In line with the current passion for multiculturalism
column9: he argues that the people involved are pretty much all equivalent
column10: and that there are no important racial differences that need to be considered. He dismisses the work of the psychometricians whose data
column11: in spite of the taboos of our current state
column12: reveal in hundreds of studies that people's intelligence vary by racial group. He throws out this data
column14: based on his own assessments of personal experience with different peoples. In fact
column15: he baldly states his belief that stone age peoples such as New Guineans (whom he knows something about) are actually on average more intelligent than white Europeans. One more example of introspective speculation and personal
column16: anecdotal experience being being mistaken for hard data that can be replicated
column19: and added to by studies with improved methodologies. His attack on such an important question as IQ and the 'wealth of nations' is weak
column23: and short. In order to see the importance of geography and race
column24: Diamond might have considered comparing the development over the last few hundred years of the peoples on the islands of Hispaniola and Iceland. Try spending a couple of hours with your browser aimed at the CIA fact book
column26: and a few other readily available sources
column27: then tell me why you think geography is the prime mover in the fate of nations! His hopes of helping to see history become more scientific
column30: certainly is meritorious. Really important questions about the history and destiny of man can and should be attacked by scientific methods
column31: and perhaps Diamond's accretion of observations and speculations do serve as a sort of start
column32: something like how alchemy started chemistry."^1^October 20

column2: ^3879406^3^0^"The book is an attempt to answer the question why the rise of complex human societies unfolded differently on different continents. The main conclusion is it was differences in continental environments
column3: not in human biology. Advanced technology
column4: centralized political organization
column5: writing
column6: and other features of complex societies could emerge only in dense sedentary populations capable of accumulating food surpluses. The domesticable wild plants and animal species essential for that rise of agriculture were distributed very unevenly over the continents. The most valuable suitable wild species were concentrated in only nine small areas on Earth
column7: which became in turn the first places suitable for agriculture
column8: which were in turn the first places to develop guns
column9: germs and steel. Descendants of those societies became dominant in the ancient and the modern world. This is
column11: the book. This is the thesis that Diamond poses at the beginning of the book and then takes 400 pages to prove- in my opinion very successfully. It makes for a compelling
column12: superbly organized read and a fantastic anti-racist thesis."^5^December 9

column2: ^3879406^2^0^"Did you know that the Americas didn't evolve the wheel because they didn't have animal power that could make a wheel useful? Or that the number 1 protein source of the world came from around Israel? Breath-taking theories about the reasons behind everything we see around us. Fascinating."^5^December 2
^3879406^2^0^"I know a lot of people who have started this book
column3: liked it
column4: but never finished it. I have finished it and have been fully rewarded through the insight it gave me about how our world has developed. The book is written to answer a question posed by a man from New Guinea to the author about the reason white men have so many things and black men so few. The answer is contained in this book and the reasons have nothing to do with 'the superiority of a race' as some are led to believe."^5^October 29

column2: ^3879406^2^0^"Jared Diamond takes a broad view of human history and argues that geography was the primary thing driving the evolution of societies
column3: making the eventual dominance of eurasian societies all but inevitable. He defends his thesis with an array of evidence from astonishingly disparate fields - genetics
column4: evolutionary biology
column5: archeology
column6: climatology
column7: linguistics
column8: and dozens of others play a role here. Altogether
column9: the author presents a fascinating case laid out in an easily understood way
column10: that's a must-read for anyone with an interest in human history."^5^November 21

column2: ^3879406^2^0^"This was consistently interesting
column3: and quite well written for the intelligent lay reader. It is flawed by Diamond's obvious bias toward proving that the fates of human societies 'don't involve human racial differences at all'. He says he objects to such racist explanations not ONLY because they are loathsome
column4: but also that they are wrong. Shouldn't truth come first? Surely they would not be loathsome if they were true? However
column5: he was thorough enough that I was absolutely convinced of his arguments. And happy to be so."^5^April 8

column2: ^3879406^1^0^"This book was a definite eye opener on a variety of subjects. For me
column3: parts two (The Rise and Spread of Food) and three (From Food to Guns) where the most interesting. I was amazed to learn how natural selection already started with food domestication and how the first farmers were already practicing a primitive form of genetic engineering. It was also astonishing to learn that the first full blown (although unintentional) form of biological warfare was waged against the Native Americans by the early American settlers. By the time the settlers reached mid America
column4: there were almost no Native American's left to be displaced because they had been wiped out by the likes of influenza and small pox. Learning that most human diseases originated in animals also shed new light on the bird flu epidemics of recent times. It's also worth considering that if the Chinese hadn't given up on building sea worthy ships
column5: America might have a very different racial mix right now (this was also covered in Kim Stanley Robinsons alternate history book called 'The Years of Rice and Salt'). The begining of the book is a bit tough to get into but once you do it becomes easier except towards the end where the author tries to apply 'what you've learned' to why the world is the way it is which doesn't have the same pace as previous chapters. All in all an educational and interesting read."^4^October 31

column2: ^3879406^1^0^"Whenever I read a book that I really like
column3: I always check out the bibliography to see if there are other books on the subject that I might like to read. I pay special attention to books that are specifically mentioned in the text of whatever book I am reading. Lately
column4: one title has come up over and over
column5: 'Guns
column6: Germs
column7: and Steel'. I read it when it was published in 1997. Because so many authors are using it in their research
column8: I decided that it was time to read it again. Rereading this book was a pleasure. Enough time has passed since my first reading
column9: that I experienced those 'aha' moments again. Moments when what the author is saying is so clear and makes so much sense that I find myself wondering why I have never looked at the subject in that light before. His thesis is very simple. The reason that Eurasian peoples conquered and colonized the world was not because they were smarter than the so-called primitive societies that they encountered. Instead
column10: the reason was simply that they had more plants and animals in their environment that were suitable for domestication which led to population increases which led to more people to come up with technological inventions such as the writing and sophisticated weapons. Peoples lacking enough plants and animals in their environment that were suitable for domestication either got a later start at food production and technology or never moved beyond the hunter-gatherer stage. Which is not to say that they were any less intelligent. My favorite anecdote is about two English explorers who perished while attempting to traverse the outback of Australia
column11: an area where the aboriginal tribes had been able to find enough food and water to survive with no problem for thousands of years. And while it is true that many conquered peoples died from the diseases that were introduced by Europeans
column12: those same Europeans died of tropical diseases at the same rates until 20th century medicine was able to overcome them. It's no surprise that this book has become a classic. Nor should it surprise anyone that it is the Ur text for anyone writing on climate

column2: ^3879406^1^0^"Diamond gives a convincing argument that geography played a much larger role in the shaping of human destiny that had previously been appreciated."^4^November 21

column2: ^4543330^2^0^"Roger Crowley's pageturner gets good mileage out of presenting the fall of Constantinople as a decisive and open moment. In reality
column3: it was not a 'clash of Islam and the West'
column4: as the West chose not to involve itself for the leftover city of the Byzantine Empire. All the surrounding areas had already been gobbled up by the Ottoman Empire. Similar to Monty Python's black knight unwilling to admit defeat
column5: the Byzantine ruling class decided to go down fighting instead of adopting the pragmatic solution of the hard-nosed Genoese who observed the siege in safety across the Golden Horn. Minus the fake clash of civilizations bit (much cherished by conservatives everywhere)
column6: Crowley's account is a quick and enjoyable read."^4^January 31

column2: ^4543330^1^0^"This is my third Crowley book and least favorite
column3: even though it's his most popular (by LibraryThing ownership stats) and his first book. Still
column4: it is informative and entertaining. Chronologically it falls somewhere between City of Fortune and Empires of the Sea
column5: it would be good to read them in order as it gives broader historical context. This book is focused on a single event
column6: the Fall of Constantinople in 1453
column7: which is truly seismic as it kicked off centuries of conflict between Europe and the Ottoman Turks; and shifted European attention away from the east and outward into the Atlantic. Stories about Medieval sieges are like dramatic genre novels
column8: if you read enough of them they often follow similar scripts and events. This is the mother of sieges in sheer scale - of the walls
column11: the stakes (real and figurative). I'm glad to have read about it in more detail as it's one of those things you can't avoid
column12: it is one of the core markers of the end of the Middle Ages and start of the Early Modern period."^4^October 27

^605093068^2^0^"This was an Audible impulse buy
column3: but I'm glad I got it. DuBois
column4: an African-American university professor in the early 1900s
column5: wrote this book as a response to Booker T. Washington's plan for the post-slavery black community
column6: and as a documentation of the kind of demoralization
column7: fragmentation
column8: and hopelessness of black America post-Civil War. Washington's approach was pragmatic. African-Americans should stop lobbying for political rights. (Perhaps he felt it would incite too much backlash?) They should not dream of going to college
column9: but of attending technical schools and going into the trades. Black America will succeed by putting their heads down and working hard for economic prosperity
column10: with healthy doses of thrift and sacrifice. DuBois' response was that a culture needs more than bread to live on. African-Americans needed to gain the ability to think about the world they live in
column11: to articulate their experience and what they have to offer to our country. This could only come about through liberal education
column12: not trade school alone. DuBois points out that the teachers at Washington's trade schools were not trained at trade schools
column13: but at black colleges. These colleges also produced needed moral
column15: and intellectual leaders of the black community: professors
column21: work hard' doesn't even work. Du Bois documents the very real economic plight of the supposedly freed men and women. Though they are legally free
column22: they are trapped in a cycle of indebted tenant farming. The few who
column23: through ingenuity and the luck of a few good harvests
column24: save up the money to buy their own land
column25: are often cheated by whites who take their money and run. This and other structural inequalities
column26: such as poor education funding and unstable families due to the heritage of slavery
column27: expose Washington's philosophy for the canard it is - so says Du Bois. This book has made me curious to read Washington and hear his side of the story. Formerly
column29: the 'best' blacks (the house slaves) and the 'best' whites were intimate
column30: living together and having bonds of quasi-family ties; now they are segregated. How then can we understand one another? What's so sad is that most of this book can still apply today. In some ways
column31: not much has changed for African-Americans living with the legacy of slavery and subsequent political and economic disenfranchisement. As a historical work
column32: Du Bois' book is important to read 113 years later; his bristling literary style

column2: ^605093068^1^0^"W.E.B. Du Bois narrates his journeys of the South after the Emancipation of slavery. It tells of the systemic racism that was institutionalized during this time. My professor at the University of Texas at Austin told me to read this after discussion of Booker T Washington's book
column3: Up From Slavery. He said this gave a more accurate picture of the time. It was very eye-opening for me since I never studied this literature in my high school or college courses. As an education historian I used this book to make many connections about how African Americans were unfairly treated during the Reconstruction Era and beyond leading to current achievement gaps. It was a very dense book and took a lot of time to get through the content. My copy is full of highlighting
column4: notes
column5: and underlined pieces. I'm a better person for having read it!"^4^July 26

column2: ^605093068^1^0^"It is impossible to rate The Souls of Black Folk too highly. It is a worthwhile read solely for the impact that it has had upon American society
column3: both in its time and in the decades since its 1903 publication. The Souls of Black Folk was a major contribution to the African-American literary tradition
column4: and it is also a cornerstone of the literature on sociology. Beyond its historical and educational value
column5: though
column6: I highly recommend this book to everyone for the piercing glimpses Du Bois offers into the souls of all men and women. W. E. B. Du Bois first came under the spotlight by opposing Booker T. Washington
column7: a prominent member of the African-American community who emphasized the importance of accommodating the policies of race separation prevalent in a Jim Crow society. Du Bois believed that in order to attain suffrage
column10: American society had to acknowledge the wrongs done to African-Americans and strive to integrate them fully into U.S. society. His book documented the conditions of post-slavery America while simultaneously arguing for improvements in the unequal black and white communities. Du Bois was an impassioned advocate for higher education. While Washington focused on educating blacks for the trades and manual labor
column11: Du Bois insisted that blacks should have access to intellectual education rivaling that available to whites. As Manning Marable states in Living Black History
column13: and fewer still become foundational texts for the movements and struggles of an entire people. The Souls of Black Folk occupies this rare position. It helped to create the intellectual argument for the black freedom struggle in the twentieth century.' (96) However
column14: more than simply a revealing microcosm of post-Civil War and Jim Crow society
column15: The Souls of Black Folk offer brilliant glimpses into mankind as a whole
column16: regardless of color. Du Bois discusses religion
column23: and mortality. His chapter on death of his young son
column25: is some of the most impressive
column27: and passionate prose I have ever read. It is easy-at least
column28: it was for me-to pigeonhole Du Bois as a figure who did much for his race in the Jim Crow era
column29: but whose work is outdated and useful only as a historical account. However
column32: a disservice. I found his insight profound and his opinions valuable even after more than a century
column33: and I learned a lot about the nature of people. The salience of The Souls of Black Folk attests to Du Bois's insistence on the importance of an intellectual tradition
column36: in the then-emerging field of sociology. Though at times the book seems to be a rather disparate collection of essays loosely centered on African-American (and cultural) identity
column39: . to emphasize that topic's importance by displaying the ways in which racism was affecting all areas of African-American life. I have one piece of advice for enjoying this book: I listened to it on audiobook
column40: and I've discovered that I tend to pay better attention to stories than intellectual discourse in audiobook format. If you're anything like me
column41: you may want to read a paperback or e-book. You'll want to highlight dozens of passages anyway!"^4^September 27

column2: ^605093068^1^0^"Experience the last two centuries in the lives of Black Americans...feel their plight for more understanding.....to read this is to know why.!"^5^March 5
^605093068^1^0^"I can see why this book is a classic. Despite my 5-star rating
column3: it was very
column4: very tough going for me; painful at times. Nevertheless
column5: extremely worthwhile to get inside the head and passions of an extremely brilliant African-American man at the turn of the century. I suspect a great many of his ideas
column6: arguments
column7: and conclusions would be applicable today."^5^September 18

^605093068^2^0^"This was an Audible impulse buy
column3: but I'm glad I got it. DuBois
column4: an African-American university professor in the early 1900s
column5: wrote this book as a response to Booker T. Washington's plan for the post-slavery black community
column6: and as a documentation of the kind of demoralization
column7: fragmentation
column8: and hopelessness of black America post-Civil War. Washington's approach was pragmatic. African-Americans should stop lobbying for political rights. (Perhaps he felt it would incite too much backlash?) They should not dream of going to college
column9: but of attending technical schools and going into the trades. Black America will succeed by putting their heads down and working hard for economic prosperity
column10: with healthy doses of thrift and sacrifice. DuBois' response was that a culture needs more than bread to live on. African-Americans needed to gain the ability to think about the world they live in
column11: to articulate their experience and what they have to offer to our country. This could only come about through liberal education
column12: not trade school alone. DuBois points out that the teachers at Washington's trade schools were not trained at trade schools
column13: but at black colleges. These colleges also produced needed moral
column15: and intellectual leaders of the black community: professors
column21: work hard' doesn't even work. Du Bois documents the very real economic plight of the supposedly freed men and women. Though they are legally free
column22: they are trapped in a cycle of indebted tenant farming. The few who
column23: through ingenuity and the luck of a few good harvests
column24: save up the money to buy their own land
column25: are often cheated by whites who take their money and run. This and other structural inequalities
column26: such as poor education funding and unstable families due to the heritage of slavery
column27: expose Washington's philosophy for the canard it is - so says Du Bois. This book has made me curious to read Washington and hear his side of the story. Formerly
column29: the 'best' blacks (the house slaves) and the 'best' whites were intimate
column30: living together and having bonds of quasi-family ties; now they are segregated. How then can we understand one another? What's so sad is that most of this book can still apply today. In some ways
column31: not much has changed for African-Americans living with the legacy of slavery and subsequent political and economic disenfranchisement. As a historical work
column32: Du Bois' book is important to read 113 years later; his bristling literary style

column2: ^605093068^1^0^"W.E.B. Du Bois narrates his journeys of the South after the Emancipation of slavery. It tells of the systemic racism that was institutionalized during this time. My professor at the University of Texas at Austin told me to read this after discussion of Booker T Washington's book
column3: Up From Slavery. He said this gave a more accurate picture of the time. It was very eye-opening for me since I never studied this literature in my high school or college courses. As an education historian I used this book to make many connections about how African Americans were unfairly treated during the Reconstruction Era and beyond leading to current achievement gaps. It was a very dense book and took a lot of time to get through the content. My copy is full of highlighting
column4: notes
column5: and underlined pieces. I'm a better person for having read it!"^4^July 26

column2: ^605093068^1^0^"It is impossible to rate The Souls of Black Folk too highly. It is a worthwhile read solely for the impact that it has had upon American society
column3: both in its time and in the decades since its 1903 publication. The Souls of Black Folk was a major contribution to the African-American literary tradition
column4: and it is also a cornerstone of the literature on sociology. Beyond its historical and educational value
column5: though
column6: I highly recommend this book to everyone for the piercing glimpses Du Bois offers into the souls of all men and women. W. E. B. Du Bois first came under the spotlight by opposing Booker T. Washington
column7: a prominent member of the African-American community who emphasized the importance of accommodating the policies of race separation prevalent in a Jim Crow society. Du Bois believed that in order to attain suffrage
column10: American society had to acknowledge the wrongs done to African-Americans and strive to integrate them fully into U.S. society. His book documented the conditions of post-slavery America while simultaneously arguing for improvements in the unequal black and white communities. Du Bois was an impassioned advocate for higher education. While Washington focused on educating blacks for the trades and manual labor
column11: Du Bois insisted that blacks should have access to intellectual education rivaling that available to whites. As Manning Marable states in Living Black History
column13: and fewer still become foundational texts for the movements and struggles of an entire people. The Souls of Black Folk occupies this rare position. It helped to create the intellectual argument for the black freedom struggle in the twentieth century.' (96) However
column14: more than simply a revealing microcosm of post-Civil War and Jim Crow society
column15: The Souls of Black Folk offer brilliant glimpses into mankind as a whole
column16: regardless of color. Du Bois discusses religion
column23: and mortality. His chapter on death of his young son
column25: is some of the most impressive
column27: and passionate prose I have ever read. It is easy-at least
column28: it was for me-to pigeonhole Du Bois as a figure who did much for his race in the Jim Crow era
column29: but whose work is outdated and useful only as a historical account. However
column32: a disservice. I found his insight profound and his opinions valuable even after more than a century
column33: and I learned a lot about the nature of people. The salience of The Souls of Black Folk attests to Du Bois's insistence on the importance of an intellectual tradition
column36: in the then-emerging field of sociology. Though at times the book seems to be a rather disparate collection of essays loosely centered on African-American (and cultural) identity
column39: . to emphasize that topic's importance by displaying the ways in which racism was affecting all areas of African-American life. I have one piece of advice for enjoying this book: I listened to it on audiobook
column40: and I've discovered that I tend to pay better attention to stories than intellectual discourse in audiobook format. If you're anything like me
column41: you may want to read a paperback or e-book. You'll want to highlight dozens of passages anyway!"^4^September 27
